key_findings: Utilize the official WordPress Plugin Handbook as your primary resource for understanding plugin architecture and best practices: https://developer.wordpress.org/plugins/
Follow the WordPress Coding Standards to ensure your code is clean, maintainable, and consistent with the WordPress ecosystem: https://developer.wordpress.org/plugins/wordpress-coding-standards/

Implement security best practices by validating and sanitizing user inputs, using nonces for form submissions, and escaping output to prevent vulnerabilities: https://developer.wordpress.org/plugins/plugin-security/
Ensure your plugin is translation-ready by using the WordPress internationalization functions, allowing for easy localization: https://developer.wordpress.org/plugins/internationalization/
Structure your plugin with a clear directory layout, separating PHP files, assets, and languages for better organization and maintainability.
Use hooks (actions and filters) effectively to extend WordPress functionality without modifying core files, promoting compatibility and ease of updates.
Leverage the WordPress REST API for seamless integration with external applications, ensuring you adhere to authentication requirements using OAuth or application passwords.
Test your plugin thoroughly in various environments (different PHP versions, WordPress installations) to identify compatibility issues before release.
Document your code and provide clear instructions for installation and usage to enhance user experience and adoption of your plugin.

code_examples.description: Basic structure of a WordPress plugin
code_examples.code:
<?php

/**
 * Plugin Name: My Custom Plugin
 * Description: A brief description of the plugin.
 * Version: 1.0
 * Author: Your Name
 */

// Exit if accessed directly
if ( ! defined( 'ABSPATH' ) ) exit;

function my_custom_plugin_function() {
    // Your code here
}

add_action( 'init', 'my_custom_plugin_function' );

code_examples.description: Sanitizing user input in a settings form
code_examples.code:
<?php

function my_custom_plugin_settings_page() {
    if ( isset( $_POST['my_custom_option'] ) ) {
        update_option( 'my_custom_option', sanitize_text_field( $_POST['my_custom_option'] ) );
    }
}

add_action( 'admin_post_my_custom_plugin_save', 'my_custom_plugin_settings_page' );

best_practices: Practice 1: Follow WordPress coding standards for PHP, JavaScript, and CSS.
Practice 2: Use nonces for form submissions to protect against CSRF attacks.
Practice 3: Keep your plugin lightweight and avoid unnecessary dependencies.
Practice 4: Use transients or object caching to improve performance.
Practice 5: Regularly update your plugin to address security vulnerabilities and compatibility issues.
implementation_patterns: Pattern 1: Use the MVC (Model-View-Controller) pattern to separate logic, presentation, and data handling.
Pattern 2: Implement a settings API for managing plugin options and settings.
Pattern 3: Use shortcodes to allow users to easily embed functionality into posts and pages.

integration_requirements.authentication: Use WordPress's built-in user authentication and capabilities system.
apis_required: WordPress REST API for external integrations

performance_considerations: Consideration 1: Minimize database queries by using caching and optimizing queries.
Consideration 2: Load scripts and styles conditionally to reduce page load times.
Consideration 3: Use asynchronous loading for non-essential scripts.
security_considerations: Security tip 1: Always validate and sanitize user inputs to prevent SQL injection and XSS attacks.
Security tip 2: Use prepared statements for database queries to enhance security.
Security tip 3: Regularly review and update your plugin to patch any security vulnerabilities.
